entry.title: SAP MDK SAM - can't switch users without an Internet connection
entry.content:
We are using Asset Manager 2405. We cannot switch between 2 users on 1 device when the device is not connected to the internet. Both users finished onboarding + init sync. But can not switch users without an internet connection.

Is it possible to change the behaviour so users do not have to be connected to the internet when a user wants to check tasks assigned to him? I have checked the source code of SAM 2405, and I have found functions like InitializeOnUserSwitch, where I can remove actions like UploadOfflineData.action, but I do not know if it helps (is it a good idea?).

Only a connected user to the internet can access data - is it SAP MDK feature or just SAP SAM feature, and can it be changed?

entry.title: Building Pro-Code Extensions for SAP Mobile Start leveraging mobile native functionalities
entry.content:
We just concluded this year's SAP TechEd with two very insightful in-person events – SAP TechEd 2025 in Berlin (Nov 4–5) and SAP TechEd on Tour Bangalore (Nov 25–26). As depicted in the announcement blog post of my colleague Thilo Berndt, the mobile topics were again very well covered in various sessions and activities. As part of which, we were conducting a Hands-on Workshop both in Berlin and Bangalore called "CA260 – Learn how to build your own app and use it in SAP Mobile Start", which we would like to recap in this blog post and highlight the most interesting technical aspects.

Overview

SAP Mobile Start is the native entry point to the SAP Business Suite, to all relevant business processes, data, and content. It provides access to native or web-responsive business apps along with other content and critical business information. This includes notifications and consolidated views on tasks, approval workflows, and SAP S/4HANA situations. SAP Mobile Start provides business information from SAP Start, SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition, and SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. Non SAP content can be integrated as well. It runs on iOS, iPadOS and Android devices, on watchOS and Wear OS devices, and on Apple Vision

While one significant aspect of SAP Mobile Start is to provide access to SAP’s role-specific standard content, such as business applications and tiles exposed from SAP S/4HANA via SAP Build Work Zone, this year’s SAP TechEd Hands-On Workshop CA260 centered on the ease of building pro-code extensions using SAP Build and specifically SAP Build Code with the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). Participants were able to experience the necessary steps in building and deploying such a pro-code extension, as well as how to specifically utilize mobile native capabilities within that extension, such as Widgets (e.g. on the iOS Home and Lockscreen) and (Push) Notifications.

The session material and exercises are available on Github within the repository SAP-samples/teched2025-CA260. We do highly recommend checking out the exercises and trying them out on your own development system environment. This blog post will provide a brief overview of the most important steps and technical activities. 

Please note that the session material on Github as well as some screenshots and code snippets in this blog post will contain usages of "###" as a placeholder for the participant number that was assigned in the hands-on workshop. Participants were instructed to replace these occurrences with their own participant number.

Building and Deploying the base version of the extension

The exercises started by building and deploying an initial version of the extension that the workshop is using as an example. As the initial version provided to participants, we are using a slightly modified version of the "Incidents Management" CAP sample application. The provided full-stack application and its dependencies are defined in the Multitarget Application descriptor (mta.yaml) which is being built and packaged into an mta archive (.mtar) during the build operation, which eventually gets deployed to the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), specifically SAP BTP Cloud Foundry environment. While the workshop is making use of SAP Build Code and its productivity tooling for developing full-stack applications with CAP, building the MTA project and deploying the build artifact to the SAP BTP, you can as well use your IDE of choice such as Visual Studio Code.

Screenshot: Overview of the project structure

 With the deployment, the CAP application (in terms of the server logic) is running an application container on the Cloud Foundry Runtime. The UI of our full-stack application is realized using SAP Fiori Elements, which is generating the User Interface based on standard floorpans and UI annotations as part of the service definitions using CDS. The Fiori frontend application lives within the HTML5 Repository of the SAP BTP. While this would already be sufficient to expose our extension to SAP Build Work Zone and SAP Mobile Start as an application tile and run the frontend within the shell of SAP Build Work Zone using its managed Approuter, we want to have more control over the visual representation. 

Frontend deployed to the HTML5 Repository; backend application deployed to Cloud Foundry

We can achieve this greater control by leveraging SAP Build Work Zone's content definition format – the Common Data Model (CDM). The definition of which is documented here and represents a standardized data structure for defining business apps, their visual representation, the required roles, and the logical hierarchical structure in which business apps shall be organized using a concept called "Spaces & Pages". Such CDM structure can be supplied to the HTML5 Repository during deployment of our extension. In the workshop's repository, this definition resides in the /workzone/cdm.json file.

Integrating the app into SAP Build Work Zone & SAP Mobile Start

For integrating our extension into SAP Build Work Zone, which makes it automatically available to SAP Mobile Start, we leverage a relatively new feature of the SAP Build Work Zone Channel Manager – defining a HTML5 Business Solution. While we could also create a regular Content Provider, using the new Content Channel type "HTML5 Business Solution" further simplifies the process as we are not required to manage any design-time destination. The HTML5 repository is merging all deployed HTML5 applications and their CDM definition from a common "Business Solution", making it available for selection as a joint Content Channel by the "Business Solution" dropdown.

Creation of a HTML5 Business Solution Content Channel in SAP Build Work Zone

This value used for merging multiple HTML5 application belonging to the same business solution is done via a dedicated property ("service" under "sap.cloud") in the web applications manifest.json. If you want to read more about HTML5 Content Consumption capabilities of SAP Build Work Zone, we can recommend this excellent blog post from our colleague Rupam who is part of the SAP Build Work Zone team.

{
  "_version": "1.65.0",
  "sap.app": {
    "id": "com.sap.ca260.###",
    "type": "application",
    [...]
  },
  [...]
  "sap.cloud": {
    "public": true,
    "service": "ca260###"
  }
}

 After adding the Content Channel's role to our Site and making sure we have the role assigned to our desired users, we can see it exposed in SAP Build Work Zone using the browser as well as in SAP Mobile Start – Nice! As defined in the /workzone/cdm.json file, the application tile of our built extension is placed onto a Page with the title "Apps from Participant CA260-000", which itself is available under a Space named "Extensions from CA260".

Deployed application visible in SAP Build Work Zone and SAP Mobile Start

Extending the app to make use of Widgets on your mobile device

The steps to extend now our application in order for it to be configurable as a Widget, for example on the iOS Homescreen or the Lockscreen, are actually much easier than you might think. SAP Mobile Start offers multiple types of Widgets. The one we will be using here is the "Business Info Widget", which can be configured to display any KPI that is available to SAP Mobile Start. In technical terms this means that we need to enhance the application tile of our extension to become a "Dynamic App Launcher". In the simplest case, these are tiles showing a number coming from a connected data service. In more complex scenarios, these can also display criticalities, trend and more information around the selected KPI.

The process to transform our basic tile into a Dynamic App Launcher is fairly simple. Within our web application's manifest.json file, we can add the required definition to make it such a dynamic tile and connect it to our OData service for incidents available in our CAP application. For our example, let's point to the OData count of incidents and filter for incidents that are not in status closed using the status_code property. The needed configuration resides within the inbound definition under the node "indicatorDataSource". In order to make this change visible on our environment, the updated version needs to be deployed and the Content Channel needs to be synced.

Transforming the application tile into a DynamicAppLauncher

 As a result, our application now appears a KPI tile on our Site and in SAP Mobile Start and we can monitor the automatically updated value both inside of SAP Mobile Start – for example when accessing the Page or by adding the app into my favorites on the Start tab of SAP Mobile Start. This fact allows us to configure the same Dynamic App Launcher tile as a Widget, for instance to our iPhone's Homescreen.

Pro tip: Why not mirroring your iOS Widget of open incidents to your Mac or configure the same on your Apple Watch as a watch face complication?

The Dynamic App Launcher tile appearing in SAP Build Work Zone and SAP Mobile Start

 

Implementing our own (push) notifications

Let's now go one step further and implement our own notifications from our CAP application. The beauty of the integration via SAP Build Work Zone and SAP's notification framework leveraging the SAP Alert Notification Service on BTP is, that such notifications will automatically appear on our SAP Build Work Zone Site in the browser, in SAP Mobile Start under the notification bell as well as be delivered as a mobile native push notification to the mobile devices on which you use SAP Mobile Start. That's a game changer for informing your users about a time critical situation directly from your pro-code extensions.

For CAP based extensions, we can make use of the @cap-js/notifications plugin. The plugin communicates with the necessary APIs using a Destination that needs to be created in the SAP BTP Subaccount in which the application will run. By default it expects the name for the Destination to be SAP_Notifications if not configured differently. The values for this Destination can be retrieved from the Settings of SAP Build Work Zone (Administrator role required).

For sending actual notification from our CAP service, we need to define our desired NotificationTypes first in the /srv/notification-types.json. These defined types represent the blueprint for the actual notifications to be sent. They include the texts for the actual notifications in all the languages that shall be supported with dedicated placeholders which will be filled when the notification is actually triggered in the service logic. Below you can see an example for such a type:

{
    "NotificationTypeKey": "IncidentCreated",
    "NotificationTypeVersion": "1",
    "Templates": [
      {
        "Language": "en",
        "TemplatePublic": "New Incident created",
        "TemplateSensitive": "New incident created by {{customer}}",
        "TemplateGrouped": "Incident Status Update",
        "TemplateLanguage": "mustache",
        "Subtitle": "{{description}}"
      },
      {
        "Language": "de",
        "TemplatePublic": "Neuer Vorfall eingegangen",
        "TemplateSensitive": "Neuer Vorfall von {{customer}}",
        "TemplateGrouped": "Vorfall Status Änderungen",
        "TemplateLanguage": "mustache",
        "Subtitle": "{{description}}"
      }
    ]
  }

Sending actual notification is fairly easy and can be done with very few lines of code. We first need to initialize the notifications plugin with cds.connect.to('notifications'), which creates a handle with which we can send notifications later. Sending notifications can be done with the function alert.notify. Here, we reference the desired NotificationType (defined before), recipients and further properties and data related to this specific notification we intend to send.

Coding used to send notification when incidents are created and closed.

 

 

As a result, we receive a push notification at the event of incident creation and closure. Already in the push notification displayed by the mobile operating system, we see the defined texts from our NotificationType with the specific values filled for the specific incident object. When tapping on this push notification, SAP Mobile Start shows the full notification in the dedicated area of the mobile app. Using "Open in Browser" brings us to this specific incident in our SAP Fiori Elements application where we could take further action. This is achieved by supplying the Intent Based Navigation (IBN) information of our app – consisting of the Semantic Object and Action defined in our web application's manifest. This allows SAP Mobile Start and SAP Build Work Zone to open the right application as a navigation target from the exposed content – in our case, the SAP Fiori Elements application running the HTML5 Repository and exposed to SAP Build Work Zone using the HTML5 Business Solution Content Channel.  The deep link to the specific incident object is achieved by supplying a special navigation target parameter that SAP Fiori Elements supports for opening the desired "Inner App Route" – in our example, the Object Page of a specific incident using its ID. Feel free to check out how this was done for this specific example in the repositories' code.

 

The notification details visible in SAP Mobile Start and the deep-link navigation to the SAP Fiori Elements application

 

Outlook

We hope we were able to show, how easy it is to create pro-code extensions, deploy them to the SAP BTP, integrate them into SAP Build Work Zone & SAP Mobile Start. The demonstrated examples of mobile native widgets and push notifications hopefully showed the ease of leveraging the mobile native device capabilities. Beyond the content of the CA260 Hands-On Workshop of SAP TechEd 2025, we would like to give you an outlook to what else would be possible with this basis.

The beauty of using the HTML5 Business Solution Content Channel Exposure in SAP Build Work Zone is that we have the flexibility and feature set of the Common Data Model (CDM) available. We could further extend the /workzone/cdm.json file to make use of even richer visualization capabilities – for example by defining a declarative UI Integration Card. Such cards allow to achieve UI richt micro-experiences right on the Page's structure, for example displaying a short list of incidents with the most important information to get a brief overview as a processor. In the browser when consuming the page via SAP Build Work Zone, the card is rendered as a regular SAP UI5 UI Integration Card. In SAP Mobile Start, declarative cards are supported as mobile native UI elements. With a single declarative definition of such a card using the UI Integration Card framework, we can achieve native cross-platform support with a high quality user experience directly within SAP Mobile Start.

Having a UI Integration Card added to the Page in SAP Build Work Zone and SAP Mobile Start

For further information on SAP Mobile Start related features and topics, please check our SAP Mobile Start documentation. Visit SAP Mobile Experience Community Page and click “follow” to get the latest development and innovation of our solutions. We look forward to hearing about your experience with these hands-on exercises; please do share your thoughts and comments below.

entry.title: Cloud Identity Services - GitHub at Your Service To Help with Feedback
entry.content:
Good documentation grows faster and better when users and authors work together. That’s exactly the spirit behind the initiative we started some time ago by opening the SAP Cloud Identity Services documentation to community feedback via GitHub.

Your questions, issues, and edits have directly helped us improve the documentation and shape Cloud Identity Services for the community. Please continue to share your experiences — whether it’s a quick correction, a clarification, or a new example — every contribution helps.

Why this matters for Cloud Identity Services users and authors:

  • Faster fixes and clearer guidance: When you report unclear wording or missing information, we - the authors can respond and update docs more quickly.
  • Direct collaboration: Instead of waiting for a support ticket or guessing, you can open a conversation right where the documentation lives.
  • Learn and contribute: Submitting edits is a great way to share real-world tips or correct examples that help everyone.

Thank you! and keep the feedback coming. 

But how to do that? See the links in More Information below.

More Information

Identity Authentication Opens Its Documentation for Your Feedback with GitHub 

SAP Open Documentation Initiative

SAP Cloud Identity Services

entry.title: Re: Invoice Receipt Workflow with ERS (Evaluated Receipt...
entry.content:
Hello @AikoFC 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details

Supplier Invoice,  Supplier Evaluation, Workflow for Supplier Invoice Approval, How to Configure the Flexible Workflow for Supplier Invoices,

In summary to your question, in public cloud, ERS invoices do not trigger supplier-invoice workflows because workflow processing only applies to parked and balanced invoices. They are not eligible for workflow because ERS postings are automatically created from the system as documents. Due to its clean-core principle, public cloud also does not provide and configuration, BAdI or extensibility option that adds workflow support.

I suggest you use situation handling or central monitoring apps if you require governance on ERS.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: In public cloud how to get Sales Order Header Text
entry.content:
Dear @Krithik,

In Public Cloud the clean core read SO texts via the released Sales Order (A2X) API (API_SALES_ORDER_SRV)

Sales order header texts:

  • GET .../sap/opu/odata/sap/API_SALES_ORDER_SRV/A_SalesOrder('<SalesOrder>')/to_Text
    or (if you also need header fields)
  • GET .../sap/opu/odata/sap/API_SALES_ORDER_SRV/A_SalesOrder('<SalesOrder>')?$expand=to_Text

Sales order item texts:

  • GET .../sap/opu/odata/sap/API_SALES_ORDER_SRV/A_SalesOrderItem(SalesOrder='<SalesOrder>',SalesOrderItem='<Item>')/to_Text

The text payload uses fields like LongTextID / LongText (and language-dependent handling), which is exactly how A2X exposes long texts.

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3282990

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/03c04db2a7434731b7fe21dca77440da/5e78feff2ce74328b7305146f61b88da.html

https://api.sap.com/api/API_SALES_ORDER_SRV/resource/Sales_Order_Header

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/03c04db2a7434731b7fe21dca77440da/00d244581efca007e10000000a441470.html?profile=20020833

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Can the S4/HANA Public Cloud Updates overwrite my Customizing without Z or Y?
entry.content:
we have to extend some entries in IMG, e.g. the valuation classes to implement the material account determination according our customers requirement. Ideally we can do it by using the same primary keys as we have on another SAP system the customers runs. There the primary keys are fully numeric. We have concerns to follow the same nomenclature in public cloud. Will IMG entries which don’t start with Z or Y be overwritten by future updates, in the case SAP will release new standard entries which are congruent to the entries we set up.

In on premise systems you can check through the delivery class of tables by yourself. There you can identify if the table is protected against SAP updates or if you have to protect your entries by using the Z/Y namespace.

Generally we want to prevent that updates will overwrite entries we will do when customize the system.

entry.title: Re: Automatic Task creation for production posting change...
entry.content:
Dear @ST24,

In Public Cloud you currently can’t schedule WT creation for Posting Change (SPC) documents. The Schedule Warehouse Task Creation mechanism and the job-template behavior you saw with /SCWM/R_DLV_PDO_CREATE_WT_JT supports delivery types like outbound (PDO), but not posting change (SPC).

SAP even documents this limitation: Currently, it is not supported to create warehouse task for posting change (SPC) with app Schedule Warehouse Task Creation.

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3126148

What you can do instead:

  • Manual or mass creation via Warehouse Monitor: SAP recommended workaround is to use Warehouse Monitor to create WTs for posting change documents
  • If you need true scheduled/unattended WT creation for SPC in Publlic Cloud, raise an SAP incident / feature request and reference SAP Note 3126148

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Fiori Elements / Flexible Programming Model Value Help Custom Filter
entry.content:
Hi,

we're using a Standard Value Help in our FPM app (V4 with RAP) with the Valuehelp annotation

 

 @ui.selectionField: [{ position: 20 }]
     @EndUserText.label: 'Artikel'
     @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{ 
        entity: { name: '/LUNEH/BC_CIP_SHLP_ARTICLE', element: 'Article' },
        additionalBinding: [{ localElement: 'StoreId', usage: #FILTER, element: 'StoreId' }]
     }]
     Article;

 

However we would like to create a custom Filter (Checkbox) in this Value Help. Is this possible?

Currently we are creating Custom filters like this: https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/sdk/#/topic/5fb9f57fcf12401bbe39a635e9a32a4e

entry.title: Re: ERROR_SENDING_HTTP_REQUEST: HTTP Receiver Adapter
entry.content:
"An advanced mode parameter "setAuth" has been introduced. If this parameter is set to "true" in the advanced mode table, the basic authentication will be performed, when SSL is not enabled."- It says, if SSL option is enabled, then HTTP request will carry SSL attributes which will be accept at Destination service, If SSL option not enabled, then it will validate with Auth method which is added in advanced mode. Please make sure, the required certificates are updated in certificate and key repository> TrustedCAs.

Additionally, It could be cause for internet proxy. So if the http request going outside network and if internet proxy need to use, then try enable the proxy with required details. It applies for secured network connection scenario. 

Hope it will help.

entry.title: PR for Special Project Stock Transfer with STO
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

From time to time, we encounter situations where materials purchased for a project are received at the warehouse in the defined location (i.e., Storage Location 1). Instead of being delivered to the originally planned address, after a while, they need to be sent to another warehouse (Storage Location 2) for delivery to the customer site several days later.

I understand that these materials are being transferred from Storage Location 1 to 2 using a STO order, which is being generated with a manually created PR.

Do you know if there's a way to generate these PRs from the WBS (without duplicating the demand) and thus avoid the manual PR for the STO?

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Integrating Non-SAP Semi-Structured Invoices Data with SAP BDC Using SAP Databricks
entry.content:
Struggling to bridge the gap between your non-SAP data and your SAP data — without creating costly data silos or duplicates?

In this blog post, we demonstrate how SAP Databricks can efficiently extract semi-structured data like PDF invoices from an external S3 bucket, derive some insights and share the results as a customer managed data product with SAP BDC using the zero-copy approach.

This not only accelerates data-driven insights but also:

  • Lowers storage costs
  • Simplifies your data landscape
  • Supports a framework for handling other semi-structured or unstructured data, which can be a common obstacle in data and analytics strategies

This is high level how the architecture of the scenario looks like:

The source pdf files (invoices) from the S3 bucket we are reading from, have the following format:

Below is a step-by-step breakdown of what we will do and more context is provided as we progress:

  • List the prerequisites and some additional configurations
  • Install pypdf for the parsing of the semi-structured pdf files
  • Ingest the PDF invoices from our S3 bucket as binaryFile
  • Parse them with pypdf
  • Write the result into a Delta table named bt_delta_table_invoice_pdf.
  • Train a scikit‑learn RandomForestRegressor to predict Payment Delays, register it in Unity Catalog Model Registry, and do batch inference.
  • Persist the result set in the delta table bt_delta_table_invoices_payment_delay_prediction in SAP Databricks.
  • Create a Delta Share using the Delta table and publish it as a Data Product to the SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Catalog using the zero‑copy sharing concept.
  • As a last step of this blog we'll retrieve our shared SAP DBX data product in the SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Catalog

0) Prerequisites

  • SAP Databricks (Unity Catalog‑enabled workspace).
  • S3 bucket with invoices (PDFs). See this nice blog from my colleague @jing_wen on how to connect an S3 bucket as an external location in SAP Databricks
  • A Unity Catalog Volume (e.g., /Volumes/babacar/default/checkpoints) you can write to.
  • Privileges to create/alter Delta tables and register models in Unity Catalog.

1) Configuration

We are reading the pdf files from an S3 bucket in streaming mode, parsing them on the fly usingpypdf and writing to a Delta table, using a volume (e.g., /Volumes/babacar/default/checkpoints/pdf_ingest). This ensures that our streaming job can reliably:

  • track the progress of data that has been processed.
  • recover from failures by resuming from the last successful state.
  • and prevent duplicate data from being written to the Delta table.
CATALOG   = "babacar"
SCHEMA    = "default"
TABLE     = "bt_delta_table_invoices_pdf"   # <- my target table for the storage of the parsed pdf files

S3_src="s3a://vpbdcpd/NON_SAP_Unstructured/invoices/babacar/"

# Safe checkpoint path in a Unity Catalog Volume
CHKPT     = f"/Volumes/{CATALOG}/{SCHEMA}/checkpoints/pdf_ingest"

FULL_TABLE = f"{CATALOG}.{SCHEMA}.{TABLE}"

To ensures our workflows are compatible and secure in the SAP Databricks environment,we'll use /Volumes/... instead of /tmp or /FileStore for all checkpoints.

2) Install pypdf

Let's start by installing the pypdf library in our Databricks environment.

%pip install pypdf

pypdf extracts text from digitally generated PDFs (with a text layer). For scanned PDFs (image‑only pages), there is the option to use AWS Textract as a fallback (async APIs for PDFs).

3) Create the Delta table (constraints + table properties)

Now we create our target Delta table babacar.default.bt_delta_table_invoice_pdf for the storage of the extracted pdf files and add some constraints such as NOT NULL to help enforce data quality and integrity and ensure that only valid data is written to the table, preventing issues like missing required fields or invalid values.

CREATE SCHEMA IF NOT EXISTS babacar.default;

CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS babacar.default.bt_delta_table_invoices_pdf (
  Id_Nr               STRING      NOT NULL,
  Name                STRING,
  Surname             STRING,
  Sex                 STRING,
  Address             STRING,
  Invoice_Nr          STRING,
  Payment_Deadline    DATE,
  Paid_At             DATE,
  Delay               INT,
  source_file         STRING
)
USING DELTA
TBLPROPERTIES (
  delta.enableChangeDataFeed = true,     -- enable CDF
  delta.enableDeletionVectors = false    -- keep Copy-on-Write; 
);

ALTER TABLE babacar.default.bt_delta_table_invoice_pdf
  ADD CONSTRAINT chk_delay_nonneg CHECK (Delay IS NULL OR Delay >= 0);

In the above code, notice that we have configured two properties on the delta table that is created:

  • Change Data Feed (CDF) is set to true which enables row‑level change tracking for incremental consumers.
  • Deletion Vectors (DV) is set to false for compatibility (you can enable later if you want Merge-on-Read (MoR) updates).

These properties help manage how data changes are tracked and how deletes/updates are handled in our Delta table.

4) pypdf parser for invoice fields extraction

With the code below we first extract semi-structured invoice fields from PDF files by reading the PDF bytes, normalizing the text, and applying regular expressions to find key fields like ID_Nr, name, address, and dates. It uses the pypdf library to read the PDF and returns a dictionary of extracted values, handling missing or malformed PDFs. The approach enables automated extraction of relevant data from semi-structured invoice documents for further analysis.

import re
from io import BytesIO
from typing import Dict, Optional
from pypdf import PdfReader

# Define regex patterns for each invoice field to extract
_PATTERNS = {
    "Id_Nr"            : r"(?:^|\b)Id[_\s-]*Nr\b[:\s]*([A-Za-z0-9_-]+)",
    "Name"             : r"(?:^|\b)Name\b[:\s]*([A-Za-zÀ-ÖØ-öø-ÿ'`-]+)",
    "Surname"          : r"(?:^|\b)Surname\b[:\s]*([A-Za-zÀ-ÖØ-öø-ÿ'`-]+)",
    "Sex"              : r"(?:^|\b)Sex\b[:\s]*(Male|Female|Other|[MFmf])",
    "Address"          : r"(?:^|\b)Address\b[:\s]*([\s\S]+?)(?=\s+(?:Invoice[_\s-]*Nr|Payment[_\s-]*Deadline|Paid[_\s-]*At|Delay|Name|Surname|Sex)\b|$)",
    "Invoice_Nr"       : r"(?:^|\b)Invoice[_\s-]*Nr\b[:\s]*([A-Za-z0-9_-]+)",
    "Payment_Deadline" : r"(?:^|\b)Payment[_\s-]*Deadline\b[:\s]*([0-9]-[0-9]-[0-9])",
    "Paid_At"          : r"(?:^|\b)Paid[_\s-]*At\b[:\s]*([0-9]-[0-9]-[0-9])",
    "Delay"            : r"(?:^|\b)Delay\b[:\s]*([0-9]+)"
}

def _normalize_text(t: str) -> str:
    # Replace special characters and extra spaces for cleaner matching
    return re.sub(r"[ \t]+", " ", t.replace("■", " ")).strip()

def extract_invoice_fields_from_bytes(pdf_bytes: bytes) -> Dict[str, Optional[str]]:
    try:
        # Read PDF content from bytes and extract text from all pages
        reader = PdfReader(BytesIO(pdf_bytes))
        pages_text = [(p.extract_text() or "") for p in reader.pages]
        full_text  = _normalize_text("\n".join(pages_text))
    except Exception:
        # If PDF cannot be read, return all fields as None
        return {k: None for k in _PATTERNS.keys()}

    # Initialize output dictionary with None for all fields
    out = {k: None for k in _PATTERNS.keys()}
    # Search for each field using its regex pattern
    for k, pat in _PATTERNS.items():
        m = re.search(pat, full_text, flags=re.IGNORECASE|re.MULTILINE)
        if m:
            out[k] = m.group(1).strip()

    # Standardize the Sex field to "M", "F", or "Other"
    if out["Sex"]:
        s = out["Sex"].lower()
        out["Sex"] = "M" if s in ("male","m") else ("F" if s in ("female","f") else "Other")
    return out

5) Read PDF files as binary from an S3 bucket in streaming mode**

In this step, we are extracting invoice fields from each file using a custom function in a streaming mode and then we write the parsed results into the bt_delta_table_invoices_pdf table. The process handles files in small groups, keeps track of what has already been processed and ensures that nothing is missed or duplicated, even if there are problems or interruptions.

from pyspark.sql import functions as F

# Read PDF files as binary from S3 in streaming mode, select content and file path
raw = (
    spark.readStream
         .format("cloudFiles")
         .option("cloudFiles.format", "binaryFile")
         .option("cloudFiles.includeExistingFiles", "true")
         .load(S3_SRC)
         .select(
             F.col("content"),
             F.col("_metadata.file_path").alias("source_file")  # Use file path as source identifier
         )
)

# Function to process each micro-batch of files
def process_batch(batch_df, epoch_id: int):
    if batch_df.rdd.isEmpty():
        return

    # Collect all rows in the batch
    rows = batch_df.select("source_file","content").collect()
    parsed_rows = []
    for r in rows:
        sf, bts = r["source_file"], r["content"]
        # Extract invoice fields from PDF bytes
        fields = extract_invoice_fields_from_bytes(bts if bts is not None else b"")
        parsed_rows.append((
            fields["Id_Nr"], fields["Name"], fields["Surname"], fields["Sex"],
            fields["Address"], fields["Invoice_Nr"], fields["Payment_Deadline"],
            fields["Paid_At"], int(fields["Delay"]) if fields["Delay"] else None,
            sf
        ))

    if parsed_rows:
        # Create DataFrame from parsed rows and cast date columns
        out_df = spark.createDataFrame(parsed_rows, schema="""
            Id_Nr STRING, Name STRING, Surname STRING, Sex STRING, Address STRING,
            Invoice_Nr STRING, Payment_Deadline STRING, Paid_At STRING, Delay INT,
            source_file STRING
        """)
        out_df = (out_df
                  .withColumn("Payment_Deadline", F.to_date("Payment_Deadline"))
                  .withColumn("Paid_At",          F.to_date("Paid_At")))
        # Append results to Delta table
        out_df.write.mode("append").format("delta").saveAsTable(FULL_TABLE)

# Start the streaming query with checkpointing and batch processing
(
    raw.writeStream
       .option("checkpointLocation", CHKPT)
       .trigger(availableNow=True)   # Use availableNow trigger for incremental batch
       .foreachBatch(process_batch)
       .start()
).awaitTermination()

6) Verify

Let's now verify if the data have been saved successfully into the target table bt_delta_table_invoice_pdf.

The DESCRIBE EXTENDED statement provide detailed information about the table properties defined in a previous step like Change Data Feed (CDF) and Deletion Vectors (DV).

%sql
SELECT * 
FROM babacar.default.bt_delta_table_invoices_pdf
ORDER BY source_file
LIMIT 20;

DESCRIBE EXTENDED babacar.default.bt_delta_table_invoices_pdf;  -- properties (CDF/DV) visible

Result of the verification:

  • Properties of the Delta table:
  • Content of the Delta table:

Glancing at the results, we can confirm that the data has been extracted successfully and the delta table is ready to be used.

7) ML training (scikit‑learn) + UC Model Registry + inference

The first code block trains a Random Forest model to predict invoice payment delay using features engineered from the Delta table, logs the model and metrics to MLflow and registers the model as Champion in Unity Catalog. The second code block loads theChampion model as a Spark User-Defined Function (UDF) and applies it to the feature DataFrame for batch inference, adding a predicted delay column.

# Install scikit-learn if not already installed
%pip install -q scikit-learn

import numpy as np, pandas as pd, pyspark.sql.functions as F
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score, mean_squared_error, mean_absolute_error
import mlflow, mlflow.sklearn
from mlflow.models.signature import infer_signature
from mlflow.tracking import MlflowClient

CATALOG, SCHEMA = "babacar", "default"
SOURCE_TABLE = f"{CATALOG}.{SCHEMA}.bt_delta_table_invoices_pdf"
MODEL_NAME   = f"{CATALOG}.{SCHEMA}.invoice_delay_model"

mlflow.set_registry_uri("databricks-uc")  # Use Unity Catalog for model registry

# Feature engineering: create features from the Delta table
fe = (
  spark.table(SOURCE_TABLE)
       .withColumn("name_len",     F.length("Name"))
       .withColumn("surname_len",  F.length("Surname"))
       .withColumn("addr_len",     F.length("Address"))
       .withColumn("sex_idx",      F.when(F.col("Sex")=="M",1).when(F.col("Sex")=="F",0).otherwise(2).cast("int"))
       .withColumn("deadline_year",  F.year("Payment_Deadline").cast("int"))
       .withColumn("deadline_month", F.month("Payment_Deadline").cast("int"))
       .withColumn("deadline_day",   F.dayofmonth("Payment_Deadline").cast("int"))
       .select("Delay","name_len","surname_len","addr_len","sex_idx","deadline_year","deadline_month","deadline_day")
       .dropna(subset=["Delay"])  # Remove rows with missing target
       .limit(200_000)            # Limit to 200,000 rows for training
)
pdf = fe.toPandas()  # Convert to Pandas DataFrame for sklearn

# Prepare features and target
X = pdf[["name_len","surname_len","addr_len","sex_idx","deadline_year","deadline_month","deadline_day"]].fillna(0)
y = pd.to_numeric(pdf["Delay"], errors="coerce").fillna(0.0).astype(float)

# Split into train and test sets
Xtr, Xte, ytr, yte = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2, random_state=7)

with mlflow.start_run(run_name="train_invoice_delay_model") as run:
    params = dict(n_estimators=200, max_depth=8, random_state=7, n_jobs=-1)
    model = RandomForestRegressor(**params).fit(Xtr, ytr)  # Train model

    y_pred = model.predict(Xte)  # Predict on test set
    r2  = r2_score(yte, y_pred)
    rmse= float(np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(yte, y_pred)))
    mae = float(mean_absolute_error(yte, y_pred))

    # Log parameters and metrics to MLflow
    mlflow.log_params(params)
    mlflow.log_metrics({"r2": r2, "rmse": rmse, "mae": mae})

    # Log model with signature and input example
    sig = infer_signature(Xtr, model.predict(Xtr))
    mlflow.sklearn.log_model(model, "model", signature=sig, input_example=Xtr.iloc[:5])

    # Register model in Unity Catalog and set alias "Champion"
    registered = mlflow.register_model(model_uri=f"runs:/{run.info.run_id}/model", name=MODEL_NAME)
    MlflowClient().set_registered_model_alias(MODEL_NAME, alias="Champion", version=registered.version)

print({"r2": r2, "rmse": rmse, "mae": mae})

UC Model Registry uses 3‑level names (catalog.schema.model) and the databricks-uc registry URI.

😎 Batch inference (Spark UDF) with the Champion version:

This part of the pipeline operationalizes the trained invoice delay prediction model. It first engineers the same features used during training from the latest invoice data. The registered MLflow model Champion is loaded as a Spark UDF (User-Defined Function) and applied to these features, generating a predicted payment delay for each invoice. The results are then written to a Delta table babacar.default.bt_delta_table_invoices_payment_delay_predictions for persistent storage and easy downstream analysis.

from pyspark.sql import functions as F
import mlflow

PREDICTIONS_TABLE = "babacar.default.bt_delta_table_invoices_payment_delay_predictions"

# Feature engineering: create features for prediction
features = (
    spark.table(SOURCE_TABLE)
    .withColumn("name_len", F.length("Name"))           # Length of Name
    .withColumn("surname_len", F.length("Surname"))     # Length of Surname
    .withColumn("addr_len", F.length("Address"))        # Length of Address
    .withColumn("sex_idx",                             # Encode Sex as integer
        F.when(F.col("Sex") == "M", 1)
         .when(F.col("Sex") == "F", 0)
         .otherwise(2).cast("int")
    )
    .withColumn("deadline_year", F.year("Payment_Deadline").cast("int"))   # Year of deadline
    .withColumn("deadline_month", F.month("Payment_Deadline").cast("int")) # Month of deadline
    .withColumn("deadline_day", F.dayofmonth("Payment_Deadline").cast("int")) # Day of deadline
    .select(
        "name_len",
        "surname_len",
        "addr_len",
        "sex_idx",
        "deadline_year",
        "deadline_month",
        "deadline_day"
    )
)

# Load the registered MLflow model as a Spark UDF
predict_udf = mlflow.pyfunc.spark_udf(
    spark,
    model_uri=f"models:/{MODEL_NAME}@Champion",
    env_manager="local"
)

# Apply the model to the features to get predictions
scored = features.withColumn(
    "predicted_delay",
    predict_udf(F.struct(*features.columns))
)

# Write predictions to a Delta table, overwriting if it exists
scored.write.mode("overwrite").option("overwriteSchema", "true").format("delta").saveAsTable(PREDICTIONS_TABLE)

# Display the predictions
display(scored)

9) Share the prediction Delta table to SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) (Delta Sharing)

Let's now create a share BT_DDP_dbx_s3_invoices_predicted, grant access to SAP BDC as a recipient, enabling secure data sharing from Databricks to external consumers. A share is a mechanism for distributing and accessing data across different systems. Creating or updating a share involves including specific attributes, such as @openResourceDiscoveryV1 in the request body, aligning with the Open Resource Discovery protocol. This procedure ensures that the share is properly structured and described according to specified standards, facilitating effective data sharing and management.

Let's install first the BDC Connect SDK:

%pip install sap-bdc-connect-sdk

Then create the share or update it, if already existing:

from bdc_connect_sdk.auth import BdcConnectClient
from bdc_connect_sdk.auth import DatabricksClient

bdc_connect_client = BdcConnectClient(DatabricksClient(dbutils, "sap-business-data-cloud"))

share_name = "bt_ddp_dbx_s3_invoices_predicted"


open_resource_discovery_information = {
    "@openResourceDiscoveryV1": {
        "title": "CP_dbx_dp_s3_invoices_prediction",
        "shortDescription": "The table contains data related to invoice predictions and actual outcomes.",
        "description": "The table contains data related to deadlines and predictions of delays. It includes metrics such as the lengths of names, surnames, and addresses, as well as demographic information and specific deadline dates. This data can be used for analyzing patterns in delays, understanding the impact of personal information on deadlines, and improving project management processes."
            }
        }

response = bdc_connect_client.create_or_update_share(
    share_name,
    open_resource_discovery_information
)
print(f"[REQUEST] Create or update share request was executed and returned {response}")

10) Create or update share CSN

The CSN serves as a standardized format for configuring and describing shares within a network. To create or update the CSN for a share, it's advised to prepare the CSN content in a separate file and include this content in the request body. This approach ensures accuracy and compliance with the CSN interoperability specifications, facilitating consistent and effective share configuration across systems.

from bdc_connect_sdk.auth import BdcConnectClient
from bdc_connect_sdk.auth import DatabricksClient
from bdc_connect_sdk.utils import csn_generator

bdc_connect_client = BdcConnectClient(DatabricksClient(dbutils, "sap-business-data-cloud"))

share_name = "bt_ddp_dbx_s3_invoices_predicted"

csn_schema = csn_generator.generate_csn_template(share_name)

response = bdc_connect_client.create_or_update_share_csn(
    share_name,
    csn_schema
)
print(f"[REQUEST] Create or update CSN request was executed and returned {response if response else 'OK'}")

11) Publish a Data Product

A Data Product is an abstract representation of a specific type of data or dataset within a system, tailored to meet specific business needs, streamline management and allow sharing across multiple platforms. It bundles resources or API endpoints to enable efficient data access and utilization by integrated systems. Publishing a Data Product allows these systems to access and consume the data, ensuring seamless communication and resource sharing.

from bdc_connect_sdk.auth import BdcConnectClient
from bdc_connect_sdk.auth import DatabricksClient
from bdc_connect_sdk.utils import csn_generator

bdc_connect_client = BdcConnectClient(DatabricksClient(dbutils, "sap-business-data-cloud"))

share_name = "bt_ddp_dbx_s3_invoices_predicted"

response = bdc_connect_client.publish_data_product(
    share_name
)
print(f"[REQUEST] Publish Data Product request was executed and returned {response if response else 'OK'}")

12) Retrieve your shared Databricks Data Product in SAP BDC Catalog

Use the title of the share defined in the ORD document in step 9

We can search for it in the BDC Catalog in SAP Datasphere or in the SAP BDC Cockpit. Please bear in mind that the newly published data product might take a couple of minutes to appear in the SAP BDC Catalog:

You can find more information about the data product in the Properties and the Details sections. This data product would qualify as a customer managed or custom data product.

The data product is now ready to use and share for all analytical and AI/ML use cases!

--------------------------------------------

In the next blog part: Scheduling the Databricks job using the BDC Datasphere Task Chain to get updates from the ML model

entry.title: Re: Serial Number Profile : Prefix (CBC activity 103636)
entry.content:
Good day @adrien_delanoe 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details

Serial Number Management, Warehouse Serialization Settings, Serial Number Profile, Material Serial Numbers in Production Orders, Serial Numbers in Inventory Management, Warehouse Management System

In summary, the prefix in SSCUI 103636 applies only to the Warehouse Serialisation in EWM. It is not used for inventory Management serial numbers or for classic WM (this also does not exist in public cloud). The numbers created during goods receipt or equipment creation will never show the prefix.

For you to use the prefix, you must activate the material in the warehouse serialization procedure in EWM. The public cloud does not show IM/WM scenarios, which is why the prefix does not appear.

Below is a guidance on how you can make the serialisation procedure field appear.

First, open the Manage Product Master Data app

Choose your product and go to the Warehouse Management

Then click on create

Thereafter, maintain your Warehouse Number, Plant, Party Entitled to Dispose.

Save the product and the serialisation fields will appear. Once the warehouse extension is created, your system will add the required details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: New in Customer Insights Dashboard: Learning Section
entry.content:
The Customer Insights Dashboard (CID) has been enhanced with a new Learning section, giving SAP customers deeper visibility into their enablement activities with the SAP Enterprise Support Academy.

This addition provides an easy way to understand how your organization is engaging with the enablement offerings available in the SAP Learning Hub, edition for SAP Enterprise Support — all within the CID view you already use for consumption and adoption insights.

What You’ll Find in the Learning Tab

The new Learning section provides insights into your organization’s learning activities and engagement trends across a wide range of enablement assets, including:

  • Expert-guided Implementations (EGIs)
  • Meet-the-Expert (MTE)
  • Learning Programs
  • E-learnings

(Note: Best Practice Documents and Tutorials are no longer actively offered but may still appear in historical consumption data.)

 

You can access the new view directly from the SAP Enterprise Support Academy card in the Summary tab in CID, which displays key learning KPIs such as:

  • Total learning activities – covering access, enrollment, and completion events
  • Distinct learning assets – unique assets consumed by your organization
  • Assigned learning programs – number of assigned learning program

 

Explore Your Learning Data

The Learning tab offers several interactive charts and tables to help analyze learning engagement:

  • By Deployment Model - See consumption patterns by deployment type — Cloud, onPremise, or Cloud_and_onPrem (hybrid). Each asset is tagged according to its deployment model, helping you understand which enablement areas your organization focuses on.
  • By Delivery Method - Get an overview of consumed enablement assets by delivery format, such as EGI, MTE, or E-learning. Each delivery type is color-coded by deployment model for quick comparison.
  • Top 10 Consumed Learning Assets - Easily identify your most popular enablement topics, including the number of learning activities and their delivery formats.
  • Detailed Table View - Access detailed records of learning activities in a tabular format. Use the settings () icon to customize columns, apply filters, or group results according to your needs. 

  • Data Coverage - The learning data model includes activities from the current year plus the previous two full years, ensuring a comprehensive view of your enablement engagement over time.

 

Why It Matters

With the Learning section, you can better understand how your teams are leveraging SAP Enterprise Support enablement offerings:

  • Track consumption in key learning assets
  • Identify training trends and gaps
  • Measure engagement across solutions and deployment models

This insight supports a data-driven approach to enablement planning and ensures that your organization continues to make the most of SAP Enterprise Support Academy resources.

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud – Error when creating billing do...
entry.content:
Hello @LDB 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details

Posting Periods, Financial Closing, Preliminary Billing Documents, Setting Posting Dates, Date Validations

That error is caused by your FI posting period control and not by billing configuration. Billing documents adopt the billing date as the posting date and in your tenant the future period (December 2025) is not opened in SSCUI 102001. Therefore, the system requires a date earlier than 28.11.2025.

You can resolve the issue by opening the corresponding future posting period. After the period is open, the system will accept your future billing dates.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Is Intercompany Asset Transfer Across Different Count...
entry.content:
Dear @Aanchal,

That error is effectively SAP telling you this scenario is not supported by design in SAP Public Cloud. The standard Post Transfer app explicitly requires that the source and target company codes belong to the same country/region.

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('ABT1L')/S35

 

  • SAP Help Portal documentation for the Transactions family states the prerequisite: “The company code of the target asset is within the same country or region”

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3e5fcf2c768746049b5627bd5a42f720/f0a16409fbc649b896add04c1c0a624e.html

So if company codes XXXX and YYYY are assigned to different countries/regions, the backend check raises FAA_POST303 and there isn’t a missing note to apply in Public Cloud to enable it this is a functional restriction of the delivered process

Best Regards,

Dawid

Hi Team,

I got a requirment from business which is i got find to done with customization with the help of enhancement,

Purpose / Objective:

The purpose of this Business requirment implementing a TDS (Tax Deducted at Source) threshold limit configuration in SAP.
Currently, the system deducts TDS on every invoice amount without checking the cumulative transaction value for each vendor at PAN.

This leads to incorrect or non-compliant deductions.

The objective of this development is to ensure that TDS is deducted only after the total transaction value for a PAN exceeds the statutory threshold limit (₹50,00,000) within a financial year.

Business Requirement

TDS should be deducted only when the cumulative invoice/payment value for a vendor PAN in a financial year exceeds ₹50,00,000.
The system must check the total amount posted for each vendor PAN from the start of the fiscal year (April) and apply TDS only when the threshold is crossed.

 

Functional Requirements:

 

TABLE

Description

INPUT Logic.

FIELD

OUTPUT                               

LFA1

Fetch Vendor by Vendor PAN detail.

Vendor PAN

J_1IPANNO

Vendor Code of same PAN

LFBW

Pass Vendor Code and get the vendor with withholding tax type 194Q-4Q

Vendor Code which I got from LFA1(J_1IPANNO)

WITHT

Vendor Details which only have TDS type 194Q-4Q

As a Functional i have created the logic but i am confuged with from which table i can pick vendor invoice amount( which is final net amount after all kind of case which can reduce vendor invoice line item except vendor payment) I triend with BSEG, But BSEG is very big table, It will not work with BSEG. Please help me with the other solution other than BSEG, I avoid BSEG here, If only BSEG help here please give a clear logic. But provide any other solution.

Can we do this by Configuration level, According to me its cannot possible because at config level its just set the invoice base amount for tds deduction but validation required on cummulative vendors at PAN level also

entry.title: Re: Function Import - The specified HTTP method is not allowed for the resource identified by the Da
entry.content:
Hi together,

This behavior is actually by design in SAP Gateway for OData V2. When you create a Function Import in SEGW and assign the HTTP method POST, the return type cannot be a collection (0..n). It must be either None, Single Entity (1), or Nullable (0..1).

The reason is that POST is intended for operations that create or modify resources, and the OData V2 specification does not allow a POST Function Import to return multiple entities. If you try to define a return type with multiplicity 0..n, the framework will reject it, and you may encounter errors like:

{
  "fault": {
    "faultstring": "Received 405 Response without Allow Header",
    "detail": {
      "errorcode": "protocol.http.Response405WithoutAllowHeader"
    }
  }
}

Solution: Return cardianlity: 1 or 0..1


This is a limitation of the OData V2 protocol and the SAP Gateway implementation, not a bug.

entry.title: How the Transition to SAP Cloud ALM Roadmap Answers Your Top 5 Transition Questions
entry.content:
Are you nervous when trying something new? I certainly am. No matter if we are talking about something simple like a new type of food, something more complex like a new travel destination, or even something that is going to impact my day-to-day life, like a new tool. What I do to try to minimize this feeling and really enjoy the experience is to research it and see what others are thinking and saying about it. 

With that in mind, I want to help you enjoy your move from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM by answering 5 frequently asked transition questions and showing you how to use the SAP Activate for Transition to SAP Cloud ALM roadmap to your advantage. 

1. How do we assess our readiness and plan our transition project using the roadmap? 

The first thing that may pop into your mind is whether you are ready to make this move, given the capabilities you already use. To help with this, we recommend you the task Perform SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM, as this will allow you to track the capabilities you are currently using in the SAP Solution Manager system, check if there are equivalent ones in SAP Cloud ALM, create possible actions plans for the functionalities that are not available, and identify other useful capabilities SAP Cloud ALM offers. 

Once you have this information, you will be able to do your Transition Planning and define if you need to do one or multiple projects based on your needs and what the next steps are. The different project types are: SAP Cloud ALM for Operations, SAP Cloud ALM for fast-paced cloud implementations, and Transition of existing ALM processes from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM, and you can find additional information about them in the deliverable Transition Planning and subsequent tasks. 

 Additional materials: 

  • Section ‘Functional comparison – what goes where?’ in the website Transition to SAP Cloud ALM  
  • Details about SAP Readiness Check can be found in the blog Availability of SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM and in the SAP Note 3236443 - SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM 

 2. Which ALM functions should we move first — operations or implementation? 

This decision depends on the challenges you are facing, the scope you determined in your SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM and the goals you want to achieve. The Transition to SAP Cloud ALM roadmap does not enforce one path, but provides you with resources to analyze your current landscape, decide based on your business needs and then guide your steps along the way. 

A generic approach indicated in the Transition to SAP Cloud ALM website, under the section ‘Transition steps and recommended sequence’ would be to start with the SAP Cloud ALM Operations to gain visibility into system health and monitoring; afterwards, adopt SAP Cloud ALM for Implementation so you can move at your own pace and also complement your implementation of other SAP Cloud solutions within your landscape; and lastly, add SAP Focus Run for advanced operations use cases, if necessary. 

Additional materials: 

  • Task Request SAP Cloud ALM Tenant 
  • Task Self-Enable on SAP Cloud ALM 
  • Accelerator SAP Cloud ALM – Functional Overview 

 3. Can we run SAP Solution Manager and SAP Cloud ALM in parallel (hybrid)? 

You can run both systems in parallel during the transition phase, as this will allow you to get to know SAP Cloud ALM, respect your business needs, and ensure a smooth migration. The important thing in this process is to understand the readiness of your system, plan your transition (Transition Planning deliverable), set your priorities (task Define Implementation Strategy), and define responsibilities (Project Initiation and Governance deliverable).  

 4. What data and documents can we migrate from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM — and when? 

The data and documents migration plan is established by you since the Prepare phase of your project, with the deliverable Data Migration Approach and Plan and subsequent tasks, when you will define the scope of this migration, estimate requirements, assign roles and responsibilities, and communicate with the relevant stakeholders. Besides that, we also have the Perform SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM task in the Prepare phase, that will provide you with insights into the assets created in the SAP Solution Manager, such as processes, documents, and test cases, that may be relevant for Selective Data Transfer. 

In the Explore phase, you will refine this plan during the Fit-to-Standard Workshops and Data Load Preparation deliverable activities, so you are able to perform your migration smoothly when you come to the task Execute Data Migration in the Realize phase. 

5. How can we upskill and prepare our team for the transition to SAP Cloud ALM? 

That is a valid concern! A transition to a new tool requires more than data analysis; we need people ready and confident to meet this new demand. The Transition to Cloud ALM roadmap takes this into account and provides you with several opportunities throughout the project’s phases to prepare your team. 

Right at the beginning, we have the deliverable Request Initial System Access that will help you gain and provide access to SAP Cloud ALM. Afterwards, with the intention of enabling your team to learn about SAP Cloud ALM and its different elements, we have the deliverable Customer Team Self-Enablement and the tasks underneath it, providing you with different steps and accelerators like the SAP Cloud ALM Learning Portal, for example. 

Besides that, we also recommend you check the tasks Establish Project Governance, Set Up Project Team Logistics and Infrastructure, and Prepare Project Team Onboarding, which will help you build your team and assign roles and responsibilities, as well as provide all the needed tools for your stakeholders to act during the project. 

 ---

Whether you’re already using SAP Cloud ALM or just exploring the first steps for this transition, the end goal is the same: have a guided path to help you have more confidence and simplicity in your day-to-day. The SAP Activate for Transition to SAP Cloud ALM roadmap is not just a timeline, but a decision-support tool to help you choose your path, assess your status, and plan your next steps. 

I hope this blog was able to help you address a few of the top-of-mind questions and how the SAP Activate Transition to Cloud ALM roadmap can help with them. Do you have other questions or suggestions about this roadmap? Leave a comment below or provide feedback in Road Map Viewer. We will be happy to help!

entry.title: How to activate the Object Store in SAP Datasphere?
entry.content:
**Updated December 2025**

Symptom: You want to activate Object Store in SAP Datasphere, but you don't know how. 

Highlights:

  • You can create up to five spaces using the Object Store option.
  • Depending on your system, Object Store may take up to 1h to be available.
  • The deployment time for creating a file space can take some time (up to 45 min).
  • There is currently no ability to enable Object Store for existing spaces; you need to create a new one, named file space.
  • Downsizing SAP HANA Storage is not possible. It is only viable via deletion and recreation of your SAP Datasphere tenant.
  • There is no limitation regarding data center and region availability for Object Store: it is available in all data centers that SAP Datasphere is available on.  

Requirements:

  • Ensure you have at least 4151 Capacity Units (CU) for the tenant. For more information, click here.
  • Confirm that you are the system owner or have the DW Cloud Administrator role assigned to proceed with this action.
  • Make sure your SAP Datasphere tenant is on version 2021.03 or later. 

Resolution: 

1. Open your SAP Datasphere, log in, and open the navigation bar. 

2. Select "System", then click "Configuration". 

3. Go to the "Tenant Configuration" tab. 

4. In the "Base Configuration" card, select "Memory" for Performance Class. 

5. Increase Memory to 128GB and Storage to 384GB. 

6. In the “Object Store” card, set Storage to 1 GB, Compute to 1 Block-Hour, and Requests to 1,000 API Calls. If you need additional resources, feel free to adjust the Storage, Compute, and Requests values as needed.

7. Click "Save". 

8. Press "OK" if you agree with all statements regarding this upgrade. 

9. Wait 1h until Object Store is available. 

10. Go to "Space Management" and hit "Create".

11. Select "SAP HANA Data Lake Files" in Storage Type and press "Create". 

12. Now you have a space with Object Store enabled. 

Image 01

Image 2

Image 3

Image 4

Image 05

Image 06

Image 07

Sources:

  • 3525760 - Activation of object store in SAP Datasphere
  • 3538038 - Important considerations for SAP Datasphere object store
  • 3224686 - How to scale down your SAP Datasphere tenant
  • Configure the Size of Your SAP Datasphere Tenant

entry.title: Re: How to Calculate VAT for PO and get in the Standard f...
entry.content:
Good day @Yathurshika_Sathiyavarman 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details

Form Templates, Key User Extensibility, CDS Views for Purchase Orders, Enable Custom Fields in the Purchasing Process, App Extensibility: Create Purchase Order via Purchase Requisition Assignment List

To summarise, in public cloud, the MMM_PUR_PURCHASE_ORDER PO form Template does not expose VAT for each item because SAP does not include pricing conditions in the standard data source. You can extend the form by using a Custom CDS View that is based on API I_PurchaseOrderItemAPI01, then expose the tax fields through a Form Data Source Extension and bind them in the Adobe form. Your VAT summation and gross calculation must happen in XDP form logic.

 

Go to the Custom CDS Views app

Create a new one.

Choose I_PurchaseOrderItemAPI01 as your primary data source. (For reference purposes I used a phrase from your topic in the following screens)

In your Elements tab, click Add and choose elements

A new window opens choose as displayed and OK.

Choose the paths (e.g., PurchaseOrder, PurchaseOderItem, etc.) you require.

Then publish

Next you need to extend the PO Form Data Source. Go to Maintain Form Template Data Source Extensions. Select MM_PUR_PO_OUTPUT, click Create Extension, add your Custom CDS View as an extension node: (Node name: ZPO_ITEM_TAX) and join PurchaseOrder + PurchaseOderItem. Then publish.

Thereafter, go to Manage Form Templates app, Copy MM_PUR_PURCHASE_ORDER, download PDF, add fields under the item node: VAT per item, Net amount, Gross amount.

Next is to add your VAT summation in Adobe. Finally upload and activate your modified template back into Manage Form Templates and assign it to your MM_PUR_PO_OUTPUT and Channel.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Global account cost centre sync issue
entry.content:
Hi All, 

We have created Global account "def19557-89f7-4fee-b33e-9c26d1a9acd2" under cost centre 101830049. In recent days, for testing provisioning flow, we changed it to 101039103. 

It causing issue with tenant creation via URM. We raised a ticket to UCL team - https://jira.tools.sap/browse/NGPBUG-467218

They responded stated that cost centre change has not synced properly.

UCL stores global accounts based on events from the CIS service. 

Most of the events we received for the global account: "def19557-89f7-4fee-b33e-9c26d1a9acd2" contain the correct cost center: "101039103"

However, there are 5-6 events that contain the wrong cost center (101830049) for the mentioned global account.

Example:

{
			"id": 86951888,
			"actionTime": 1762421251765,
			"creationTime": 1762421253194,
			"details": {
				"description": "Global account updated.",
				"globalAccountDescription": "Testing Build Work Zone",
				"guid": "def19557-89f7-4fee-b33e-9c26d1a9acd2",
				"displayName": "pdptest",
				"subdomain": "pdptest",
				"customerId": null,
				"expiryDate": null,
				"commercialModel": "Subscription",
				"costCenter": "101830049",
				"costObjectType": "COST_CENTER",
				"costObjectId": "101830049",
				"geoAccess": "STANDARD",
				"licenseType": "DEVELOPER",
				"renewalDate": null,
				"serviceId": null,
				"crmTenantId": null,
				"useFor": "Development"
			},
			"globalAccountGUID": "def19557-89f7-4fee-b33e-9c26d1a9acd2",
			"entityId": "def19557-89f7-4fee-b33e-9c26d1a9acd2",
			"entityType": "GlobalAccount",
			"eventOrigin": "accounts-service",
			"eventType": "GlobalAccount_Update"
		},

This leads to the override of the correct cost center.

Can you help us in resolving the issue. 

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: SAP Hands-on Workshop: SAP Signavio BPM
entry.content:
¡Inscríbete aquí!

Duración: 4 horas

Fecha: 12 de diciembre

Descripción:  SAP Signavio se ha consolidado como una de las principales herramientas a nivel global para modelar, optimizar y gestionar procesos de negocio de manera colaborativa. En el contexto de la transformación digital actual, la gestión de procesos es esencial para aumentar la eficiencia, calidad y agilidad en las organizaciones. Este hands-on busca cerrar la brecha entre el conocimiento teórico de BPM y la capacidad práctica para diseñar procesos bajo estándares profesionales.

Como parte de la Iniciativa Académica de SAP Signavio BPM, los participantes—compuestos por profesores y estudiantes—aprenderán a navegar y utilizar el SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub y a modelar procesos utilizando BPMN 2.0. No se requiere experiencia previa con SAP Signavio, ya que el hands-on ofrece una experiencia práctica y directa.

Dirigido por Alfredo Armijos De La Cruz, con una vasta experiencia en gestión de proyectos y transformación empresarial, el taller abarcará desde la introducción a los conceptos fundamentales de BPM hasta el desarrollo en modelado práctico con casos reales. La aprobación se basará en la realización de quizzes y la práctica guiada dentro de la plataforma SAP Signavio Process Manager.

Hora de inicio: 09:00 AM (UTC-5)

Hora de finalización: 01:00 PM (UTC-5)

¡Bueno saberlo!

  • ¡La inscripción es GRATUITA! 
  • Por favor, tenga en cuenta que no habrá una respuesta perfecta para cada pregunta/sección para todos los datos requeridos en el proceso de registro, ya que el sitio web/la tecnología que utilizamos es un sitio web de eventos universal de SAP. Le pedimos amablemente que elija la opción que mejor se adapte a usted.
  • Recomendamos seleccionar "Higher Education & Research" en el campo "Industry", "Partner" en el campo "Relationship with SAP" y "Delegate" en el campo "Function". La opción que elija no influirá en el estado de su registro.
  • Para completar tu registro, es necesario usar un correo académico o uno vinculado a una universidad.

    No dude en contactarnos con cualquier pregunta a través de Universityalliances@sap.com.


¡Inscríbete aquí!

entry.title: Re: No edocument created in ecockpit (SAP Public Cloud)
entry.content:
Hi Janarthan,

I don't have personal experience with this but did some research (Joule for Consultants) and sharing it on - alot seems rooted around the guidance from this blog as a starting point t validate proper setup:
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/electronic-invoicing-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition/ba-p/13578774

and I would guess you've already browsed the Belguin HELP documentation? https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/fba518519f834ed99011786d831ee504/2f9ab027fadc4a52bd2316d3b7e45223.html

These were the joule recommendations though:

Primary Diagnostic Steps

1. Check eDocument Cockpit Status Since you cannot access tables directly in Public Cloud, use the eDocument Cockpit or Manage Electronic Documents app to check the document processing status. Look for any error messages in both the application log (content issues) and interface log (integration issues) - Tobias' blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/electronic-invoicing-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition/ba-p/13578774

2. Verify Belgium-Specific Configuration The Belgium eDocument implementation requires multiple configuration steps that must be properly implemented [2]. Key areas to verify include:

  • Scope Item Activation: Ensure scope item 5XU (SAP Document and Reporting Compliance) is activated in your system [1]
  • Feature Activation: Activate Document and Reporting Compliance Features through Central Business Configuration (CBC) or Solution Builder [1]
  • Party ID Type Assignment: Confirm your Belgium company code is properly assigned to the BE:VAT party ID type
  • Business Partner Configuration: Verify the customer's Belgium VAT number is correctly assigned as a party ID type [1]
  • eDocument Type Mapping: Check that your billing document type is properly mapped to the Belgium eDocument type (BE_INV for invoices, BE_CRE for credit memos)

3. Configuration Activities Review Navigate through the following configuration sections [1]:

  • General Settings for eDocument: Review all general eDocument configuration activities
  • Belgium-Specific Configuration: Check country-specific settings for Belgium electronic documents

Common Root Causes in Public Cloud

1. Value Mappings Issues Most eDocument submission errors in Public Cloud relate to missing value mappings [1]. Use the Configure Value Mapping app to verify:

  • Navigate to the Belgium namespace
  • Check all required value mapping tables are properly maintained
  • Note that value mappings are not transported and must be maintained separately in each system [1]

2. Master Data Requirements Verify required master data attributes on :

  • Business Partner: Belgium VAT number properly maintained in identification tab
  • Product Master: Required classification codes for Belgium

3. Integration Setup For Belgium, you typically integrate with SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition or a third-party provider. Verify:

  • Communication arrangements are properly configured
  • Integration flows are active and functioning
  • Service connectivity is established

Troubleshooting Process

  1. Review eDocument Cockpit: Check for any processing errors or status indicators
  2. Validate Configuration: Use the configuration activities to verify all Belgium-specific settings
  3. Check Value Mappings: Ensure all required mappings are maintained for Belgium
  4. Verify Master Data: Confirm VAT numbers and other required data are properly maintained
  5. Test Integration: Verify the connection to your eDocument service provider

If you've reviewed those sources and it's sitll not resolved, I'd recommend a ticket on component FI-LOC-CA-BE

entry.title: Re: ADBC: sending input parameter error
entry.content:
The error occurs because the Calculation View parameter is being passed as a column reference instead of a literal value. input parameters must be supplied via PLACEHOLDER with a quoted literal, for example:

 
(PLACEHOLDER."$$CTRY$$" => '{ p_land1 }')

After correcting the SQL string and quoting the parameter, the view executes without error.

Replace your SQL string v_str = SELECT * FROM.........(PLACEHOLDER."$$CTRY$$" => '{ p_land1 }') .

Debug step will show
(PLACEHOLDER."$$CTRY$$" => 'IN')
